overview: Following review by the House Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, this measure is now recommended to pass Third Reading, indicating legislative advancement despite a previous committee's amendment to stall the bill for further discussion (HB70_HD1_HSCR1060_). The bill's purpose remains to enhance financial transparency for condominium associations by removing the good faith defense for boards that omit required budget summaries and placing the burden of proof on the association in legal disputes (HB70_HD1_HSCR1060_). Testimony submitted to the committee continues to show a sharp divide between supporters who see it as a necessary enforcement tool and opponents who fear it will lead to excessive litigation (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_).
economic_impact: New testimony reinforces the potential economic effects on condominium owners, citing specific instances of yearly fees around $15,000 (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_) and a construction defect settlement of $15 million (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_) with monthly interest of about $14,000 (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_). Testimony also mentions a potential landscape contract reduction of up to $80,000 (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_) that could be applied to subsequent assessments. Opposition testimony consistently warns that the measure, as written, may expose associations to 'costly frivolous litigation' over inadvertent and minor omissions in budget summaries (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_).
policy_impact: The key policy development is the House Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs' recommendation that the measure pass Third Reading, moving the bill forward in the legislative process (HB70_HD1_HSCR1060_). The central policy debate continues to revolve around the removal of the 'good faith' defense and the shifting of the legal burden of proof to the association. Numerous opponents have proposed a specific policy amendment, suggesting the 'good faith' defense should only be unavailable when a board 'completely omits' the required summary, in order to prevent litigation over minor errors (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_).
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This fiscal note is updated to reflect the bill's progression through the House Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs, which has recommended it for Third Reading (HB70_HD1_HSCR1060_). New testimony has introduced additional financial details, including a $15 million (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_) settlement and yearly owner fees of approximately $15,000 (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_). Additionally, the policy impact section is updated to include a specific amendment proposed by multiple testifiers to mitigate potential litigation risks (HB70_HD1_TESTIMONY_JHA_02-25-25_).
